properties.name: Lavender Lounge Tea Company
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 104 N. El Camino Real, B, San Clemente, CAThe 400-square-foot second-floor lounge overlooks beachy downtown San Clemente. The lavender-themed room offers an assortment of teas, including a "flight" of five teas for 0, where you can pick from a tea-tasting list to sample one tea at a time. Open 10 a.m.-7-ish p.m. Monday-Thursday; 9 a.m.-9-ish p.m. Friday- Saturday; 10 a.m.-5-ish p.m. Sunday. Reservations recommended for seating in the tiny shop.

properties.name: Anne Taintor's studio in New Mexico
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 3395 Highway 96, Coyote, NMAnne Taintor Incorporated (505) 638-5919

properties.name: Baby Donut Company
properties.description: Posted by Baostar15030 Ventura Blvd., Ste. 2, Sherman Oaks, CA 91403(818) 995-0140 At Baby Donut Company you’ll feel like a kid again. It’s like a create-your-own-sundae bar for doughnuts. Start with a glazed goodie made in-house. Then add the filling of the day (chocolate mousse, strawberry, or apple pie). Choose an icing — marshmallow, caramel, or chocolate, to name a few — and finish it off with your favorite candy topping, like M&M’s, Kit Kats, or sprinkles. They’re baby-size - and with more than a hundred combinations at 70 cents apiece, you may decide to hang out for a while.

properties.name: Little Tree Church
properties.description: Posted by Baostar El Camino Real, Tustin, CAA tiny eight-seat chapel, nicknamed "Little Tree Church," at Jamestown Village (El Camino Real, between Main and Sixth streets) in Old Town Tustin. According to a history column by Tustin native Juanita Lovret, builder C.T. Gilbreath constructed the chapel around an old oak tree after the completion of Jamestown Village in 1962. Gilbreath had razed a magnificent Victorian home for the center, and wanted to save the oak tree in the parking lot. The chapel is a miniature version of a Tennessee church that his grandmother used to visit. The companion tree died years ago, so nowadays, the church stands alone. One day\'s rental costs just 00, but you have to clean and decorate the chapel yourself. If interested, call Gerda Brucks of Gerda\'s Antiques: (714) 832-4932.

properties.name: The Hotdogger
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 129 E Street, Davis, CA 95616This wiener-sized café provides limited counter-seating for about five. They serve classic all-beef Chicago Dog with German mustard, tomatoes, diced onion and relish, spicy Ortega Dog with green chilies and pepper jack cheese, Louisiana hot links with chili, salsa, onion and many more.

properties.name: The Tiny Waterfall
properties.description: Posted by OleanderDubuque IowaSomewhere in this region there is a state park with the tiniest waterfal I have ever seen. It flows into a round pool of dark bluegreen water and simply hums with the energy of fairy folk.

properties.name: World's Smallest Park moving for 6 months.
properties.description: Posted by Jason  SW Naito & Taylor, Portland, ORThe world\'s smallest park - as recognized by the Guinness Book of World Records - is about to move... but only temporarily. Due to road construction, Mill Ends Park (24 inches across and located at the intersection of downtown Portland\'s Southwest Taylor Street and Naito Parkway) will be moved 80 feet from its current location. The park will reside in the plaza area of Portland\'s World Trade Center complex for approximately six months. According to Portland Parks & Recreation officials, a move was necessary to protect the tiny green space from the threat posed by the much larger construction equipment. (What Portlanders won\'t do to protect the environment.) When the Naito Parkway roadway improvements are completed in six or seven months, the park will be moved back to a new location on Naito Parkway, 7.5 feet east of its current home. The big - or little - move takes place on Tuesday, Feb. 7. Some sort of "mobile platform," perhaps an all-terrain vehicle, will be used to move the park in its entirety. Mill Ends Park, which was dedicated as an official city park in 1976, is one of 200 parks managed by Portland Parks & Recreation. Note: At this time, the city has no plans to move Portland\'s 5,000-acre Forest Park.
